snippet: Fund-raising goals make it virtually certain that neither nominee will accept public funds or the spending limits that come with them.
abstract: Fund-raising goals set by both presumptive Republican nominee Mitt Romney and Pres Obama, as well as Republican- and Democratic-leaning outside groups, make it virtually certain that neither party's nominee will accept public funds for the general election or the spending limits that come with them; fact that neither candidate will opt for public financing is likely to be the death knell for a cornerstone of the post-Watergate campaign finance reforms intended to limit the influence of money in federal elections.
lead_paragraph: Fund-raising goals make it virtually certain that neither nominee will accept public funds or the spending limits that come with them.

headline.main: In Cash Push, 2 Campaigns Likely to Reject Public Funds
headline.print_headline: Campaigns Plan Maximum Push to Raise Money
